newsitem.title: UK: SOCCER-ARSENAL'S TITLE HOPES WRECKED BY LATE EQUALISER.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-ARSENAL'S TITLE HOPES WRECKED BY LATE EQUALISER.

text.p: Arsenal's slim title hopes all but disappeared on Saturday when they conceded a late equaliser to draw 1-1 at Highbury with 1995 champions Blackburn.
Arsenal took an early lead through former England captain David Platt but midfielder Garry Flitcroft equalised in the 89th minute of a tense tie to deny the Gunners a crucial three points.
Arsene Wenger's side go second, level on points with Liverpool, but both teams are five points adrift of leaders and champions Manchester United who have a game in hand on both of them.

United, who face Borussia Dortmund in a European Cup semifinal on Wednesday, took a giant leap toward their fourth league title in five years when they beat Liverpool 3-1 at Anfield earlier in the day.
Newcastle stay fourth after they overturned a 1-0 deficit to beat Derby 3-1.
At the bottom, League Cup beaten finalists Middlesbrough lost 1-0 at home to neighbours Sunderland while fellow strugglers Coventry, Southampton, Nottingham Forest, West Ham and Everton all drew.
Arsenal, who had won five of their previous six matches to rekindle their trophy hopes, desperately needed another victory to keep in touch with an imperious Manchester United.
After 18 minutes defender Martin Keown met a Dennis Bergkamp cross with a firm downward header which struck the post.
The rebound fell kindly for Platt, who stroked the ball past Blackburn keeper Tim Flowers for his third goal in three games.
But Arsenal failed to increase their lead to the obvious annoyance of the home fans on a cold, blustery afternoon in north London.
Blackburn, still not guaranteed a place in the premier league next season, got better as the match went on and finally grabbed their equaliser with less than two minutes of normal time remaining.
Flitcroft met a Kevin Gallacher corner with a crisp volley from 15 metres which flew into the roof of David Seaman's net.
Despite eight minutes of extra time at the end of a bad-tempered match in which nine players were booked, Arsenal failed to find a winner which would have taken them to within three points of United.
United now look certain to clinch their 11th league title while Liverpool and Arsenal face a fierce battle for England's second European Champions' League place.
At the bottom, Middlesbrough ended a miserable, energy-sapping week with what could prove a significant defeat.
Darren Williams, who grew up supporting Middlesbrough, scored the only goal of a scrappy game at the Riverside stadium to give Sunderland a 1-0 victory which lifts them out of the relegation zone.
Middlesbrough conceded a last minute goal to draw 3-3 with second division Chesterfield in the F.A. Cup semifinal last weekend and lost the League Cup final to Leicester in extra-time on Wednesday.
They now face a replay against Chesterfield on Tuesday night before resuming their fight for premier league survival.
In the other relegation battles, bottom club Nottingham Forest were held 1-1 by Leeds, while Southampton and West Ham both squandered 2-0 leads to draw 2-2 with Coventry and Everton respectively.
